## Flow Development

### Hydrodynamic Entrance Length

$$\frac{L_{h,\text{lam}}}{D} \approx 0.05 \, \text{Re}_D$$

$$\frac{L_{h,\text{turb}}}{D} \approx 10$$

### Thermal Entrance Length

$$\frac{L_{t,\text{lam}}}{D} \approx 0.05 \, \text{Re}_D \, \text{Pr}$$

## Fully Developed Flow

### Laminar (Re < 2300)

| Boundary Condition | Nu |
|-------------------|---:|
| Constant wall temperature | 3.66 |
| Constant heat flux | 4.36 |

### Turbulent (Re > 10,000)

**Dittus-Boelter:**
$$\text{Nu}_D = 0.023 \, \text{Re}_D^{0.8} \, \text{Pr}^n$$

where $n = 0.4$ for heating, $n = 0.3$ for cooling.

```{python}
def nusselt_pipe_turbulent(Re: float, Pr: float, heating: bool = True) -> float:
    """Dittus-Boelter correlation for turbulent pipe flow."""
    n = 0.4 if heating else 0.3
    return 0.023 * Re**0.8 * Pr**n

# Example: Water in a pipe
Re = 50000
Pr = 7  # Water at ~20°C
Nu = nusselt_pipe_turbulent(Re, Pr, heating=True)
print(f"Nu = {Nu:.1f}")
```

## Key Takeaways
- Entrance regions have higher heat transfer

- Boundary condition matters for laminar flow
